nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights and improve prediction, decision-making, and accident prevention in reliability engineering and safety applications
Machine learning comprises supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning categories, each with distinct tasks and algorithms
Supervised ML (regression and classification) is widely used for remaining useful life (RUL) estimation, degradation prediction, and fault diagnosis
Unsupervised ML (clustering and anomaly detection) supports early fault/damage detection and operational mode discovery, often from streaming sensor data
Semi-supervised and reinforcement learning address problems with limited labels and sequential decision-making for maintenance and control; Safe RL incorporates safety constraints during learning
Deep learning (DL) excels on high-dimensional, nonlinear, and temporal data and has outperformed many shallow ML methods in PHM, anomaly detection, and RUL prediction

Key obstacles for ML adoption in reliability and safety include uncertainty quantification, deployment considerations, false alarm rates, computational costs, limited labeled data, and interpretability
ML methods estimate a mapping f-hat from features X to labels Y; choice of method depends on data labeling, problem type, and assumptions (smoothness, cluster, manifold)
Evidence: SVR, GPR, RNNs, LSTM, CNNs, and DNNs have been applied to RUL and degradation across batteries, bearings, engines, turbines and show improved prediction accuracy
Result: Model-based and data-driven RUL approaches exist; data-driven ML methods reduce need for physical priors and can dynamically update predictions with uncertainty estimates (e.g., GPR)

Evidence and examples: CNNs enabled end-to-end bearing fault detection from raw sensor data; LSTM detected contextual anomalies in spacecraft telemetry; SDAE+ELM improved gas turbine anomaly detection
Evidence and claim: DRL can address large state/action CBM and inspection scheduling problems where MDP/POMDP scale poorly; Safe RL methods incorporate constraints to avoid hazardous exploration
Claim: DL architectures (CNN, LSTM, autoencoders, DBN) can automate feature extraction, handle streaming and multimodal data, and improve anomaly and health-state detection accuracy

Conclusion and recommendation: Future work should prioritize uncertainty quantification, fleet- and system-of-systems PHM, integration of ML with accident and near-miss databases and safety management systems, wearable sensor analytics, and adoption of advanced models (deep Gaussian processes, GANs)
Assumption: Better uncertainty quantification and deployment-aware ML will increase operational adoption by reducing false alarms and enabling informed decision-making

Claim: Deep Gaussian Processes and Generative Adversarial Networks are promising tools for improved uncertainty estimation, generative modeling, and handling high-dimensional reliability and safety data
